Click here to create surveys.

anxiety.feedback:
has two main aspects: feeling nervous and worrying.
Feeling nervous is the uneasy or sick feeling you get when you think about your university work, assignments, or exams.
Worrying is your fear about not doing very well in your university work, assignments, or exams.
anxiety.importance: A bit of anxiety can be helpful, but too much can hinder you in your study. Overcoming your anxiety may lead to an easier time concentrating or remembering things. If your anxiety worries you, don’t hesitate to reach out for support.

thermos.contact: For problems or questions, contact L.B. de Vreugd

disengagement.feedback: is the feeling of giving up on a particular university subject or studying in general.
disengagement.importance: If you can overcome your disengagement, you are more likely to believe there is more you can do to avoid failure or attain success. As well as, become more interested in university or university work.

thermos.empty_feedback: Please click on an aspect in a graph for feedback.

feedback.score: Based on this survey, <u>you</u> scored <u>yourself</u> on {{constructName}}: {{score}}.
feedback.score-criterion-norm: </br>For {{constructName}}, the recommended percentage for studying successfully (criterion reference) is: {{norm}}%.
feedback.score-peer-norm: </br>For {{constructName}}, the average score of your peers (peer reference) is: {{norm}}%.
feedback.tips: For tips and activities on how to improve, click below

failure_avoidance.feedback: is when you do your university work mainly to avoid doing poorly, rather than to aim for success or improvement. Or that you avoid being seen as doing poorly.
failure_avoidance.importance: If you can overcome failure avoidance you tend to no longer fear failure, feel pessimistic, or feel anxious when thinking about or doing your university work.

interpersonal_group_work_skills.feedback: are those skills necessary for working with others or in a team e.g. effectively resolving conflict, understanding information exchange networks, and providing social support.
interpersonal_group_work_skills.importance: Advanced interpersonal group work skills will likely improve the experience of working with others, through positive and supportive social interactions and enhanced communication.

intro.feedback: Give feedback about the Thermos tool.
intro.message: These visualizations show your self-assessment on Motivation and Engagement, and Groupwork skills. The scores can change as you change, click on an aspect to receive tips and feedback.
intro.message_no_results: There is no data to display yet.
intro.start: Click here to complete the survey

thermos.intro_no_results: There is no data to display yet.

learning_focus.feedback: is the extent to which you are focused on learning, solving problems, and developing skills. If you feel successful and gain satisfaction in mastering what you have set out to do.
learning_focus.importance: If your learning focus increases, you tend to enjoy learning more, study for your own satisfaction and not just for rewards and enjoy challenges.

thermos.mobile_warning: The dashboard was designed for a desktop or laptop and may not work optimally on a smartphone.

persistence.feedback: is how long and how hard you keep trying to work out an answer or to understand a problem even when that problem is difficult or challenging.
persistence.importance: If you are persistent you tend to achieve what you set out to do more often, be more motivated to succeed, and be good at problem solving.

planning.feedback: is how much you plan your assignments and study. It is also about whether you keep track of your progress as you are doing your university work.
planning.importance: If you plan your university work you are more likely to feel in control of your progress, succeed in challenging university work, and make good use of your time and your abilities.

thermos.result_history.title: Results history

self_belief.feedback: is, with regard to your studies, your belief and confidence in your ability to succeed in university, meet the study challenges, utilize learning opportunities, and perform to the best of your ability.
self_belief.importance: If you have positive self-belief you tend to do difficult study tasks confidently, feel optimistic, try hard, and enjoy university.

self_sabotage.feedback: is when you do things that reduce your success at university e.g. procrastinating or wasting time when you are meant to be studying for an exam.
self_sabotage.importance: If you overcome your self-sabotage, you tend to make the most of your ability, feel good about being at university, and achieve as highly as you are able.

thermos.study_progress.title: Study progress

task_group_work_skills.feedback: are those skills necessary for the successful completion of group assignments e.g. establishing goals, planning and sequencing activities, or coordinating group interdependencies.
task_group_work_skills.importance: Advanced task group work skills will likely improve the experience of working with others, through the efficient use of time and productive meetings. As well as, reducing social loafing (‘free-riding’ or ‘meeliften’).

task_management.feedback: is the way you use your study time, organize your study timetable, and choose and arrange where you study.
task_management.importance: If you manage your study well, you tend to be more efficient. This can be done by studying in places where you can concentrate, using your study time well without getting distracted, and sticking to a study timetable.

uncertain_control.feedback: is when you are unsure about how to do well or how to avoid doing poorly.
uncertain_control.importance: If you are uncertain in control you can feel somewhat helpless when doing your university work, fear failure, or have negative thoughts about your university work.

thermos.user_agreement:
Dear student,

You’re about to use the THERMOS-tool. This tool is still under development so any help and feedback is greatly appreciated.

Please note that you should by no means feel pressured into using this tool. If so, do not continue and close this window. Furthermore, if you proceed to use the Thermos-dashboard, you confirm to have read and understand this statement, and agree to your (pseudonymized) data being stored and used to further develop this tool, the implementation in educational context, and/or for research purposes. If you do not agree, do not continue and close this window.

This text will briefly explain what data will be processed and stored, who will have access to it, and how this data helps the development of this tool.

What data is collected, why, and with what purpose?

With this tool we want to offer you support in studying at Utrecht University, by providing insight in your study behavior and helping you develop this. Your data is collected and processed for this purpose by Utrecht University and the principle behind the use of this information is the justified interest of Utrecht University.

We have composed a survey with questions about Motivation and Engagement, and Groupwork skills. Some questions are quite similar, which is not a trick but the way these surveys work. The survey used in this dashboard only measures aspects of your study behavior, not (e.g.) indications of your mental health.

After you’ve completed this survey, the data will be presented to you in a visualization. You can click on the topics you’re interested in to get feedback on how to work on these topics. After you’ve finished the survey and examined the tips and feedback, you can give us your opinion and feedback about this version of the tool. To do so, go to the ‘provide feedback’ section. We are curious to know how you’ve experienced the tool’s current look, the usefulness of the feedback and tips, and whatever comes to mind when you’re using the tool.

Apart from the personal data you provide in the surveys, the dashboard shows some personal (study progress) data from Osiris, specifically current study program, EC's obtained and average grade obtained in current study program. In order to show you this data in the dashboard, a SAML-token is used. By using this token, your SOLIS ID and the associated personal data cannot be traced within the Thermos dashboard. Lastly, while using the dashboard, your online behavior will be logged.

Where is the data stored and for how long?

The survey, feedback, and logdata are stored on a secured UU-server. To ensure protection of the data a penetration test was performed in 2019 by a third party, revealing minor issues that have been resolved. Only project members have access to the data. The data remains available until you are no longer a student at UU. After that, the data is pseudonymized and remains available for research purposes (for 10 years, recommended by the VSNU), in accordance with UU’s privacy statement (last modified on 17th of May 2018). UU has the right to update this statement when necessary. The data is processed based on UU’s legitimate interest to improve provided education. Data will not be shared with third parties or with countries outside of the European Economic Area.

Who has access to the data?

Your teachers or tutors will not be able to view your data. You can, of course, show them your results if you want their help, but only if you want to. The stored data will only be accessible to THERMOS-project members and will be used to further develop the tool or for research purposes. Before your data is used for development and/or research purposes it will be pseudonymized. When pseudonymized, aggregated data can be used to give study programs an overarching view of the measured constructs for that specific study program.

What rights do I have?

You have several rights as a Thermos dashboard user; the right to inspect your data, to rectify data, to remove data, to limit data collection, to object data collection, and data portability. To exercise any of these rights, get in touch with l.b.devreugd-2@umcutrecht.nl, or with privacy@uu.nl to do so anonymously.

With whom can you get in touch for questions or complaints?

For questions or complaints about the project, feel free to send an email to l.b.devreugd-2@umcutrecht.nl. If you want to get in touch with the UU privacy officer, send an email to privacy@uu.nl.If you want to file an official complaint with the ‘Autoriteit Persoonsgegevens’, see www.rijksoverheid.nl/contact/contactgids/autoriteit-persoonsgegevens. Further information on the project can be found on thermos.sites.uu.nl.

Responsible for the data processing is Utrecht University, Heidelberglaan 8, 3584 CS Utrecht, info@uu.nl

valuing.feedback: is how much you believe what you learn at university is useful, important, and relevant to you or the world in general.
valuing.importance: If you value university, you tend to be interested in what you learn, persist when university work gets difficult, and enjoy university.
